channel.title: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD)
channel.description: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD) generated by script

item.title: Australia’s “deep concern” at multilayered persecution of Afghanistan’s Hazaras
item.description: A parliamentary motion highlights systematic violence against a community facing ethnic, religious and gender-based repression.

item.title: Sudan’s civil war spills well beyond the battlefield
item.description: Washington’s sanctions and Tehran’s expanding reach are exposing deeper power struggles and ideological networks.

item.title: Redirecting COP31 funds could deliver Australia’s most important climate contribution yet
item.description: The $1 billion saved from not hosting could deliver more impact through Pacific infrastructure than any summit.

item.title: How Trump Brought Netanyahu to Heel
item.description: Across the region, he has made it harder for Israel to act militarily.

item.title: Decoding the Trump-Xi Phone Call
item.description: The leaders talked trade, Taiwan, and—likely—Japan.

item.title: Ukraine Agrees in Principle to Revised U.S. Peace Proposal
item.description: But major points of contention remain unresolved, including possible territorial concessions.

item.title: Kyiv Agrees in Principle to Revised U.S. Peace Plan
item.description: But major points of contention remain unresolved, including possible territorial concessions.

item.title: The wrong sort of peace leads to the next war
item.description: Donald Trump’s approach to peacemaking ignores crucial lessons from history

item.title: Japan’s New Prime Minister Is Already Facing Her First Crisis
item.description: Sanae Takaichi may be relishing confrontation with China.

item.title: Google has pierced Nvidia’s aura of invulnerability
item.description: But the search giant’s custom chips may prove tricky for others to adopt

item.title: Middle East Dispatch newsletter: A tale from Tehran
item.description: Nick Pelham writes about his visit to Iran to interview the country’s foreign minister

item.title: A high gold price is luring prospectors to California’s mountains
item.description: The new gold rush is on

item.title: The United States Is Moving Through the Stages of Grief Over China’s Rise
item.description: The Trump-Xi agreement may be a sign the U.S. position is shifting.

item.title: John Bolton thinks America is past “peak Trump”
item.description: Donald Trump’s former national security adviser speaks to The Economist

item.title: Colombia’s armed groups are experimenting with deadly drones
item.description: Drone warfare is becoming Latin America’s latest criminal innovation

item.title: The Missing Ingredients for Peace in Palestine
item.description: The Trump administration's ceasefire agreement in Gaza could be the first step toward peace, but only if it evolves into a full-fledged plan that recognizes and appreciates the decades-long Palestinian struggle and allows new Palestinian leaders to emerge. As matters stand, these basic conditions are not being met.

item.title: The killing of a Hizbullah commander shows how fragile truces are
item.description: Israel’s ceasefire agreements in Gaza and Iran and are shaky, too

item.title: How China Achieved Innovation Without Freedom
item.description: Though China remains a one-party state that disappears dissidents and censors ideas, it has vaulted past Japan, Germany, and France to become the world’s tenth most-innovative economy. It owes this achievement – which was long considered impossible – to a pioneering strategy of "smart authoritarianism."

item.title: There’s more to cholesterol than simply “good” or “bad”
item.description: Standard health tests may miss those at most risk

item.title: Ukraine Loses Again
item.description: Amid a corruption scandal, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky may well be able to convince EU leaders to remain focused on the “real enemy”: Russia. But further revelations will weaken his position in negotiations with a US administration eager for a foreign-policy victory, leaving ordinary Ukrainians to pay the price.

item.title: Stablecoins for a universal basic income: The Pacific Islands model
item.description: Digital payment systems are emerging as a substitute for inadequate regional banking infrastructure.

item.title: Can Modi Turn India into a Developed Economy by 2047?
item.description: Achieving Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi's ambitious goal will require far more than accelerating economic growth. Without stronger institutions, improved education, and updated infrastructure, India’s current momentum will not be enough to sustain long-term development.

item.title: Former Defense Minister Nakatani Says Japan’s Next Submarine ‘Will Eventually Need Nuclear Propulsion’
item.description: If Tokyo acquires nuclear-powered subs, it would be a significant strategic shift for the only nation to have suffered atomic bombings.

item.title: Iraq’s Elections Promise More Politicking Than Change
item.description: Perceptions of Washington’s indifference can perpetuate a risky status quo.

item.title: Trump’s Religious Freedom Agenda Needs to Extend Beyond Nigeria
item.description: The U.S. should avoid a narrow Christian focus.

item.title: Will Modi Cozy Up to Putin?
item.description: Next week, the Russian leader visits New Delhi for the first time since his full-scale invasion of Ukraine.

item.title: A Triangle Across Oceans: Australia, Canada, and India’s Minilateral Experiment
item.description: Trilateral arrangements are not uncommon in the Indo-Pacific, but this one stands apart for three reasons.

item.title: How China’s Smart City AI Is Moving Into Environmental Control
item.description: AI infrastructure is being repurposed to provide real-time ecological data – and changing the structure of urban environmental management.

item.title: South Korea Eyes Defense Exports to Europe, Middle East
item.description: Seoul had apparently picked two priority regions in its quest to become a top-four global defense exporter.

item.title: From Dialogue to Agency: Central Asia’s Strategic Transformation?
item.description: With the full inclusion of Azerbaijan and moves toward institutionalization, the region is shifting from loose consultation to a cohesive geopolitical community.

item.title: The Wobbling of King Trump
item.description: At home and abroad, his autocratic approach is starting to run aground.

item.title: What the Liberal Party Is Missing About Australia’s Energy Future
item.description: For the last decade and a half, the Liberal Party has been tying itself in knots over energy policy. The world is moving on.

item.title: Can China-Japan Relations Be Saved?
item.description: China seems to have decided to freeze out the Takaichi government for as long as it takes.

item.title: South Korean President Says Unification Is Ultimate Goal
item.description: During a press conference on his way to Turkiye, South Korean president shared his view on North Korea.

item.title: Strengthening the Astana-Tashkent Axis
item.description: Central Asia’s emerging regional architecture, its drivers, and the barriers to future progress.

item.title: Why the New Canadian-Swedish Partnership Matters
item.description: A recently signed strategic partnership between Canada and Sweden is a modest move with outsize geopolitical implications. Canada can begin to reduce its overreliance on the United States, Sweden can increase its influence and market share, and NATO will get a stronger northern flank that is less exposed to swings in US politics.

item.title: Why Are Bangladeshis Joining Russia’s War in Ukraine?
item.description: Many are duped by Bangladeshi and Russian recruitment agencies into joining the Russian army. Others are drawn by social media videos.

item.title: The Philippine Government Is Creaking Under the Weight of Scandal
item.description: Popular protest is keeping the issue of flood corruption in the news.

item.title: Why U.S. Tech Flip-Flops on China Are So Disastrous
item.description: Allies and adversaries alike know they just have to wait for the other shoe to drop.

item.title: How Xi Played Trump
item.description: Beijing gambled and is now reaping the rewards.

item.title: Moscow’s Offshore Menace
item.description: How the shadow fleet enables Russia’s hybrid warfare in Europe.

item.title: The Murky Future of Thailand’s Pheu Thai Party
item.description: With an election on the horizon, the party’s electoral appeal is waning, with neither powerful policy pledges nor inspiring leadership in sight.

item.title: Unregulated Mining Boom Pouring Toxins Into Southeast Asian Rivers: Report
item.description: According to the Washington-based Stimson Center, the past decade has seem a spike in unregulated mining activity in Myanmar, Laos, and Cambodia.

item.title: Trump Administration Ends Deportation Protections for Myanmar Immigrants
item.description: The U.S. Department of Homeland Security justified the decision on the grounds that the country has "made notable progress in governance and stability."

item.title: Nepal’s Steady But Fragile March to the March Polls
item.description: The Nepali Congress is on board and voter enthusiasm is running high. But powerful actors could undermine the vote.

item.title: If China is an Engineering State and the US a Lawyerly Society, What is India?
item.description: India’s infrastructure push shows that a country can combine the best of both worlds—characteristics of a lawyerly society and the practices of an engineering state.
